title: Apigee - API trigger
abstract:
# Apigee - API trigger
**Announcement:** Application Integration is now available for your Google Cloud project. You can now use both Apigee Integration and Application Integration within the same Google Cloud project. [Learn more](/apigee/docs/api-platform/integration/using-application-integration)
API triggers are used to directly invoke executions for integrations. API triggers can be used in [synchronous](/apigee/docs/api-platform/integration/error-handling-strategy#synchronous-and-asynchronous-error-handling) or [asynchronous](/apigee/docs/api-platform/integration/error-handling-strategy#synchronous-and-asynchronous-error-handling) mode.

## Add an API trigger
**API trigger**
- In the [Apigee UI](https://apigee.google.com) , select your.
- Click **Develop > Integrations** .
- Select an existing integration or create a new integration by clicking **Create Integration** .If you are creating a new integration:- Enter a name and description in the **Create Integration** dialog.
- Select a **Region** for the integration from the list of supported regions.
- Click **Create** .
This opens the integration in the .
- In thenavigation bar, click **+Add a task/trigger > Triggers** to view the list of available triggers.
- Click and place the **API trigger** element to the designer.## Configure an API trigger
Click the **API trigger** element in the integration editor to view the trigger configuration pane.
The configuration panel displays the **Trigger ID** , which is a machine-generated ID in the format `api_trigger/` `` . No further configuration is required for this trigger.
**Note** : You can have more than one API trigger in your integration. Each API trigger is assigned a unique **Trigger ID** .
## Considerations
When using the API trigger, the cumulative size of all the input variables can be a maximum of 8 MB. If the size exceeds 8 MB, Apigee doesn't run the integration and you will get an error.
